title: Dow turns lower for week after stronger-than-forecast payrolls data, with possible Tesla job cut worries also weighing
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA fell 162 points, or 0.5%, to 33,086.

* The S&P 500 SPX dropped 44 points, or 1.1%, to 4,132.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP shed 210 points, or 1.8%, to 12,107.

On Thursday, stocks finished higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing up 435.05 points, or 1.3%. The S&P 500 rose 1.8% and the Nasdaq Composite advanced 2.7%. Friday's decline dragged all three major indexes into negative territory for the week.

Mark Hulbert: Stock-market timers have been too quick to leap into the rally â€” and that's a risky sign

What's driving markets?

May nonfarm payrolls rose a bigger-than-expected390,000 data, versus expectations for a gain of 328,000, from an upwardly revised gain of 436,000 in April. The unemployment rate was unchanged in May at 3.6% and average hourly earnings rose 0.3% to $31.95 in May.

"Today's jobs report does not change the Fed's trajectory for the next couple of meetings where they are likely to hike in 50 bps (basis points) increments. But a broad look at the labor market paints a reassuring picture relative to the excessive tightness that existed when the Fed turned hawkish around the start of the new year," said Luke Tilley, chief economist at Wilmington Trust.

"Job openings have slowed, labor force is growing, wages are slowing, the Conference Board measure of job market perceptions has cooled, and the newswires are rife with hints of job reductions in some industries," he said, in emailed comments.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose 7 basis points to 2.981%. Gold prices GC00 dropped 0.5% to $1,861.10.

The Institute for Supply Management said its services index fell to 55.9% in May from 57.1% a month earlier.

Another focus for markets on Friday is a report that Tesla Inc. TSLA Chief Executive Elon Musk, according to Reuters, sent an email to executives ordering them to "pause all global hiring," and that employee head count needed to be reduced by 10%. He also reportedly said he had a "super bad feeling" about the economy.

Weakness in Tesla shares, down 6.9%, weighed on the Nasdaq. Markets shook off a warning by Microsoft MSFT on Thursday, but those shares were also down about 0.7%.

An increasingly gloomy tone is being heard from some corners of Wall Street. JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon earlier this week warned of an "economic hurricane,"coming due to inflation, the war in Ukraine and tighter monetary policy.

BlackRock Inc. BLK CEO Larry Fink told Bloomberg on Thursday that he expected elevated inflation for years and that "bouts of fear" would continue to create more market volatility.

Need to Know: Fink, Dimon and Musk have the blues. And one forecaster says they're not gloomy enough

Which companies are in focus?

* Coinbase Global Inc. COIN shares fell 8% after the crypto exchangeannounced an indefinite hiring freeze, a day after the billionaire Winklevoss twins announced cuts at their own crypto firm, Gemini.

* CrowdStrike Holdings Inc. CRWD shares fell 5.6% even after the security-software reported earnings, sales and a forecast that beat expectations and boosted annual guidance.

* Shares of Lululemon Athletica Inc. LULU were off 0.3% after the company reported sales that were better than Wall Street expected, with direct-to-consumer sales getting to be a slightly bigger chunk of the retailer's revenue.

* American Airlines Group Inc. AAL stock fell 5%, after the airline raised its revenue growth, but cut capacity guidance and raised its fuel-cost estimate.

* Shares of Turning Point Therapeutics Inc. TPTX more than doubled, up 116%, after the clinical-stage oncology company agreed to be acquired by biopharmaceutical company Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. BMY in an all-cash deal valuing Turning Point at about $3.77 billion. Bristol Myers shares were off 0.1%.

How are other assets trading?

* U.S. crude CL.1 rose 1% to around $118 a barrel.

* The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY rose 0.1%

* Bitcoin BTCUSD fell 2.9% to around $29,600.

* The Stoxx Europe 600 index XX:SXXP was down 1%, while London markets were closed for an extended Queen's Jubiliee bank holiday celebration.

* Markets in China and Hong Kong were also closed for a holiday. The Nikkei 225 index JP:NIK rose 1.2%.

Dow turns lower for week after stronger-than-forecast payrolls data, with possible Tesla job cut worries also weighing
